name: 3D Printing Recipe Book
description: Complete profiles for common 3D printing test prints and calibration objects

recipes.name: 3D Benchy
recipes.description: The classic 3D printing torture test. Evaluates overall print quality, bridging, overhangs, small details, and surface finish.
tips: Enable ironing on top layers for smoother hull
Increase wall count to 4 for better hull definition
Use brim to prevent warping on the bow tower
Slow down outer wall for better bridging
evaluation_points: Bridge quality over cabin
Hull definition on bow
Smoke stack hole roundness
Overall surface finish
No stringing or blobbing

recipes.name: XYZ Calibration Cube
recipes.description: Simple 20mm cube for verifying dimensional accuracy and calibrating steps/mm on X, Y, and Z axes.
tips: Print with no infill for true dimensional accuracy
Measure all three axes - X should be ~20mm, Y ~20mm, Z ~20mm
If X or Y is undersized, adjust steps/mm for that axis
If Z is undersized, adjust steps/mm for Z axis
Use brim if bed adhesion is poor
evaluation_points: X dimension accuracy (target: 20mm)
Y dimension accuracy (target: 20mm)
Z dimension accuracy (target: 20mm)
Corner sharpness
No layer delamination

recipes.name: Resonance/Tension Tower
recipes.description: Tower with varying acceleration settings to identify optimal acceleration and reduce ringing artifacts on prints.
tips: Slicer should generate stepped acceleration values automatically
Look for the height where ringing disappears or minimizes
Mark the optimal height and note the acceleration setting
Apply this acceleration limit to your regular profiles
Print direction matters - towers are typically labeled
evaluation_points: Find minimum height with no visible ringing
Note the acceleration value at that point
Check all four faces for consistency
Compare results at different print speeds

recipes.name: Retraction Tower
recipes.description: Tower that varies retraction distance and/or speed to find optimal settings and minimize stringing.
tips: Configure slicer to vary retraction distance or speed in steps
Typical range: 0-8mm retraction distance, 20-60mm/s speed
Look for cleanest tower section with minimal stringing
Too much retraction can cause grinding or clogging
Combine with temperature tower for best results
Enable combing to reduce travel moves through model
evaluation_points: Find section with minimal stringing between features
Check for blobbing or scrubbing marks
Ensure no under-extrusion from excessive retraction
Test both retraction distance and speed variations

recipes.name: Temperature Calibration Vase
recipes.description: Spiral vase mode print that tests extrusion temperature. Find the lowest temperature that still gives good layer adhesion.
tips: Print in spiral vase mode (single continuous spiral)
Start at your normal printing temperature
Lower temperature in 5Â°C increments on successive prints
Look for the lowest temperature with good layer bonding
Too cold = poor bonding, layer splits, rough surface
Too hot = drooping, stringing, blobbing
Optimal temp gives smooth surface and strong layers
evaluation_points: Check for layer splitting or delamination
Surface should be smooth, not shiny or drooping
Test by gently pulling - should not separate layers
Find minimum viable temperature for less stringing

notes: These profiles serve as starting points. Always tune based on your specific printer, filament, and environmental conditions. For best results, calibrate your esteps, PID tune your heater, and level your bed before running calibration prints.
